{
  "article_text": [
    "hyperbolic reflection groups are discrete groups of isometries of hyperbolic space generated by reflections in the faces of a polyhedron .",
    "they provided some of the earliest known examples of kleinian groups , and have been well - studied ( see [ v ] ) . in this paper , we prove that 3-dimensional hyperbolic reflection groups always contain short elements .    to be more precise , let @xmath1 be the group of orientation - preserving isometries generated by reflections in the faces of the polyhedron @xmath2 .",
    "we define @xmath3 to be half the shortest translation length among hyperbolic / loxodromic elements of @xmath1 .",
    "then we have :    * theorem 4.1 * _ ( main theorem ) let @xmath2 be a finite - volume coxeter polyhedron in _ @xmath0 . _",
    "then @xmath4 = 2.6639 ... . if @xmath2 is compact , then _ _",
    "@xmath5 = 2.1225 ... _ .",
    "remarks : + 1 .",
    "it is known ( see [ w ] ) that if @xmath6 is a family of closed hyperbolic 3-manifolds , and if @xmath7 is bounded , then @xmath8 is also bounded ( recall the _ rank _ of a finitely generated group is the cardinality of a minimal generating set ) .",
    "observe that by [ b ] , @xmath9 increases with the number of sides of @xmath2 , so theorem 4.1 is not covered by [ w ] .",
    "+   + 2 . for more about short geodesics in hyperbolic 3-manifolds , see [ ar ] .",
    "we speculate that the bounds may be sharp , but we do not know a proof .",
    "+   + * idea of proof * : to prove the main theorem , we must show that every three - dimensional hyperbolic reflection group contains a hyperbolic element with suitably short translation length .",
    "this can usually be done by finding two non - adjacent faces of the polyhedron which are suitably close ; the short element is obtained by composing the reflections in the corresponding hyperplanes .",
    "a result of nikulin s guarantees that every coxeter polygon which is not a triangle has two non - adjacent sides which are close , and a two - dimensional version of the main theorem follows easily . for most polyhedra",
    ", we can use nikulin s result to show that two non - adjacent faces are close ; the exceptions are those which contain `` non - prismatic '' faces ( see section 2 for a definition ) .",
    "we show that these exceptional cases always contain triangular faces .",
    "then , after extending to the sphere at infinity , we use combinatorics and euclidean geometry to deduce the existence of a short element .",
    "the results on hyperbolic polyhedra contained in section 3 allow us to sharpen the bound .",
    "* organization * section 2 contains basic definitions ; section 3 contains some general , technical results about hyperbolic polyhedra ; section 4 contains the proof of the main theorem .    * acknowledgments * : i would like to thank dr .",
    "alan reid for his help and encouragement .",
    "thanks also to dr .",
    "gary hamrick and david bachman for valuable conversations , dr . daryl cooper for helpful correspondence , and the referee for valuable comments .",
    "a _ convex polyhedron _ , @xmath2 , in @xmath10 is a countable intersection of closed half - spaces : @xmath11 , where @xmath12 denotes a hyperplane and @xmath13 the corresponding closed half - space .",
    "when n=2 , we use the term @xmath14 instead . if @xmath2 is a convex polyhedron in @xmath10 , we let @xmath15 denote the group of isometries generated by reflections in the bounding hyperplanes of @xmath2 .",
    "@xmath1 denotes its orientation - preserving subgroup of index 2 .",
    "we say that a finite - volume , convex polyhedron @xmath2 is a _",
    "coxeter polyhedron if its dihedral angles are all integer submultiples of @xmath16 ; if @xmath2 is a coxeter polyhedron , then @xmath1 is discrete .",
    "two faces of @xmath2 are _ adjacent _ if they share an edge . given a hyperplane @xmath17 in @xmath10 , @xmath18 will denote the isometry obtained by reflection in @xmath17 .",
    "we will denote the hyperbolic distance between two sets @xmath19 and @xmath20 in @xmath10 by @xmath21 . _",
    "given an n - sided face @xmath22 of @xmath2 @xmath23 , label the edges of @xmath22 by @xmath24 , where @xmath25 shares a vertex with @xmath26 for @xmath27 , and label the adjacent faces by @xmath28 , where @xmath22 and @xmath29 share edge @xmath25 ( we say the faces adjacent to @xmath22 are labeled `` cyclicly '' ) .",
    "we say that @xmath22 is @xmath30 if , for @xmath31 , @xmath32 implies @xmath29 is non - adjacent to @xmath33 .    by a _",
    "hyperbolic n - manifold _ , @xmath34 , we mean the quotient of hyperbolic n - space by a discrete group of isometries acting freely .",
    "if @xmath35 has torsion , the quotient space @xmath36 is a _",
    "hyperbolic n - orbifold_. the _ injectivity radius of a hyperbolic manifold @xmath37 is equal to @xmath38 _ every point x _ @xmath39 _ m is the center of an embedded ball of radius _ @xmath40 .",
    "we shall generalize this definition to the case where @xmath35 has torsion : the _ injectivity radius of a kleinian group _",
    "@xmath35 , denoted @xmath41 , is equal to half the shortest translation length among hyperbolic / loxodromic elements of @xmath35 .",
    "note that this agrees with the usual notion when @xmath35 is torsion - free .",
    "the _ injectivity radius of a coxeter polyhedron _",
    "@xmath2 is equal to @xmath3 .",
    "given an element @xmath42 of @xmath35 , we will denote its translation length by @xmath43 . _",
    "the following technical result shall be used in our proof of the main theorem .",
    "let p be a finite - volume , convex polyhedron in @xmath0 with acute dihedral angles and no triangular faces .",
    "then p has a prismatic face .",
    "if , furthermore , p is compact , then p has a prismatic quadrilateral or pentagonal face .",
    "we first consider the finite - volume case .",
    "let p be a finite - volume , convex polyhedron in @xmath0 with acute dihedral angles and no triangular faces , and suppose that p contains at least one non - prismatic face .",
    "let @xmath44 be a planar graph representing the 1-skeleton of @xmath2 ( see fig .",
    "1 ) . then there are three non - prismatic faces of p which bound a region in g consisting entirely of prismatic faces .",
    "let @xmath22 be a non - prismatic face of p , and label its adjacent faces cyclicly by @xmath45 .",
    "we have that @xmath29 and @xmath33 are adjacent for some i , j with @xmath46 ( see fig .",
    "1 ) . note that @xmath22 , @xmath29 , and @xmath33 bound a region @xmath47 , and that @xmath29 and @xmath33 are also non - prismatic . since @xmath2 contains no triangular faces , @xmath47 can not be a face . and",
    "if the sublemma is false , @xmath47 must contain a non - prismatic face @xmath48 .",
    "label the faces adjacent to @xmath48 cyclicly by @xmath49 .",
    "then for some @xmath50 with @xmath51 , @xmath52 and @xmath53 are adjacent",
    ". then @xmath48 , @xmath52 , and @xmath53 bound a triangular region @xmath54 . again , if the sublemma is false , @xmath55 must contain a non - prismatic face @xmath56 , creating a triangular region @xmath57 .",
    "since @xmath2 has a finite number of sides , this process must eventually terminate with three non - prismatic faces bounding a region containing only prismatic faces .",
    "this proves the sublemma , and the non - compact case of lemma 3.1 follows immediately .       to prove the stronger statement for the compact case",
    ", we shall need the following combinatorial lemma :    let @xmath2 be a compact , convex polyhedron in @xmath0 with acute dihedral angles .",
    "then @xmath2 contains a face with 5 or fewer edges .",
    "this follows from an euler characteristic count .",
    "let @xmath58 = number of vertices of @xmath2 , @xmath59 = number of edges of @xmath2 , and @xmath60 = number of faces of @xmath2 . since @xmath2 is a compact , convex hyperbolic polyhedron",
    ", @xmath2 is _",
    "simple_ i.e. each vertex is shared by exactly 3 different edges ( see [ a1 ] ) .",
    "so @xmath61 .",
    "we have @xmath62 .",

    "@xmath64 .",
    "so @xmath65 .",
    "so the average number of edges per face @xmath66 6 .",
    "so @xmath2 must contain a face with 5 or fewer edges .",
    "now suppose @xmath2 is compact . if all faces of @xmath2 are prismatic , we are done by lemma 3.3 .",
    "so suppose @xmath2 contains a non - prismatic face .",
    "then by lemma 3.2 , there are three non - prismatic faces of @xmath2 which bound a region @xmath47 in @xmath44 consisting entirely of prismatic faces . we need to show that @xmath47 contains a face with 5 or fewer edges .",
    "we form @xmath67 from @xmath47 by subtracting the three vertices , @xmath68 , of non - prismatic faces on the boundary of @xmath47 , and then adding a face to the exterior of @xmath47 , so that @xmath67 is topologically a sphere ( see fig .",
    "2 ) .       then , arguing as in lemma 3.3 , @xmath67 must contain a face @xmath22 with 5 or fewer edges .",
    "we claim that @xmath47 must also contain such a face . this will certainly be true unless    \\1 .",
    "@xmath22 is the face on the exterior of @xmath47 .    or    \\2 .",
    "@xmath22 is a pentagon , and @xmath22 contains one of the edges from which a vertex was deleted ( note that @xmath22 can contain at most one of the @xmath69 s , since it is prismatic ) .",
    "if @xmath22 is the face on the exterior and @xmath22 is a triangle , then we claim that @xmath47 must consist of three quadrilaterals , as in fig .",
    "3b . for otherwise",
    ", @xmath47 must contain three non - prismatic faces , contrary to assumption ( see fig .",
    "3b ) .",
    "so if the theorem is false , then @xmath67 contains at most four faces with fewer than 6 sides ; at least three of them must be pentagons , and none are triangles .",
    "we shall show that this is impossible .",
    "number the faces of @xmath67 by @xmath70 .",
    "let @xmath71 be the number of sides of @xmath33 .",
    "then @xmath72 , where @xmath60 is the total number of faces of @xmath67 .",
    "since @xmath2 is simple , the graph is trivalent , so @xmath60 is divisible by 3 ; hence @xmath73 is divisible by 6 . since also",
    "the average number of sides per face is @xmath66 6 , we have :    @xmath74 .    thus the sum is not divisible by 6 , for a contradiction .",

    "we claim that @xmath180 , in which case @xmath181 are disjoint , and @xmath182 are disjoint .",
    "otherwise , three circles would intersect to create a triangle @xmath129 with angle sum @xmath183 ( see fig .",
    "however , @xmath129 has only one positively curved side  call its curvature @xmath184  and it has another , longer side of curvature @xmath185 .",
    "so , by the gauss - bonnet formula , @xmath129 has angle sum @xmath186 , for a contradiction .",
    "hence @xmath187 and @xmath188 are both hyperbolic elements of @xmath1 . by lemma 4.3 , two of the opposite faces of @xmath125 must be less than @xmath189 apart .",
    "it follows that either @xmath190 or @xmath191 has suitably short translation length .",

    "p is a simplex_.    by [ l ] there are only nine congruence classes of compact simplices in @xmath0 . by [ m ] ( see also [ bm ] ) , eight of these contain triangle groups , so in these cases the result follows from theorem 4.3 . denote the remaining tetrahedron by @xmath212 ; label its faces @xmath213 ; and let @xmath214 be the dihedral angle between @xmath29 and @xmath33 .",
    "we have @xmath215 , and @xmath216 .",
    "let @xmath12 be the hyperplane spanned by @xmath29 .",
    "it is not difficult to construct @xmath212 explicitly in lobachevsky space and then compute the faithful discrete representation of @xmath217 in @xmath218 .",
    "then it is straightforward to compute that @xmath219 is a hyperbolic element with translation length 1.66131 ... @xmath220 .",
    "* non - compact case : *    by theorem 3.1 and corollary 4.6 , it is enough to consider the case where @xmath2 has a triangular face , @xmath142 . as in the compact case , the faces adjacent to @xmath142 form a polyhedron @xmath157 .",
    "if none of the vertices of @xmath142 are ideal , then the proof for the compact case carries over without change .",
    "so suppose @xmath142 has an ideal vertex .",
    "ideal vertices may be either tri - valent or 4-valent ( see [ a2 ] ) .",
    "if the vertices of @xmath142 are all trivalent then condition ii still holds ; condition i holds at regular vertices , and changes to an equality at ideal vertices .",
    "then the techniques from the compact case are sufficient to prove the theorem we omit the details . if one of the vertices is 4-valent , then two of the sides adjacent to @xmath142 are tangent on @xmath221 ( see fig .",
    "one may now argue as in the compact case , treating the tangent sides as adjacent with dihedral angle 0 .",
    "the theorem follows .",
    "[ a1 ] e. m. andreev , _ on convex polyhedra in loba@xmath223evski@xmath224 spaces _ , math .",
    "ussr - sb .",
    "* 10 * ( 1970 ) , 413 - 440 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we define the _ injectivity radius _ of a coxeter polyhedron in @xmath0 to be half the shortest translation length among hyperbolic / loxodromic elements in the orientation - preserving reflection group . </S>",
    "<S> we show that , for finite - volume polyhedra , this number is always less than 2.6339 ... , and for compact polyhedra it is always less than 2.1225 ... .    </S>",
    "<S> ams subject classification number : 57m50 ( primary ) ; 20f55 , 22e40 ( secondary ) </S>"
  ]
}
